statement.tex: %text Using principal value, evaluate the following \[\qquad \sin^{-1}\sin\left(\frac{3\pi}{5}\right) \] %

step.context: \textbf{Fill in the blanks}\\ %text The principal value of $\sin^{-1}x$ is an $\underline{\hspace{0.5cm}\alpha\hspace{0.5cm}}$ that lies between $\underline{\hspace{0.5cm}\beta\hspace{0.5cm}}$ and $\underline{\hspace{0.5cm}\gamma\hspace{0.5cm}}$. %
step.reason:
%text $\sin^{-1}x$ is an angle.
But \underline\text{given an $x\in[-1,1]$}, there are \underline\text{infinite} angles that have $\sin\theta = x$. So, which angle do we have in mind when we say $\sin^{-1} x = \theta$?
And so, \underline\text{by definition}, $\sin^{-1}x$ is an angle between $-\frac\pi{2}$ and $\frac\pi{2}$. This range - $\left[ -\frac\pi{2},\frac\pi{2}\right]$ - is called the \underline\text{principal range} and the value of $\theta = \sin^{-1}x$ is called the \underline\text{principal value}. %

step.context: %text Given what a principal value is, which of the following is correct? %
step.reason:
%text Did you notice that \[ \frac{3\pi}{5}\notin\left[ -\frac\pi{2},\frac\pi{2} \right] \]? In fact, $\frac{3\pi}{5}\gt \frac\pi{2}$. Therefore, $\frac{3\pi}{5}$ cannot be the principal value.
However, notice that % \begin{align} \sin\frac{3\pi}{5} &= \sin\left( \pi-\frac{3\pi}{5} \right) = \sin\frac{2\pi}{5} \\ \text{And }\frac{2\pi}{5} &\in \left[ -\frac\pi{2},\frac\pi{2} \right] \\ \therefore\sin^{-1}\left( \sin\frac{3\pi}{5} \right) &= \frac{2\pi}{5} \end{align}
